references: Universal (convex) optimization methods and theory for personalized FL. To develop an optimization theory for solvingÂ (1), we impose particular assumptions on the objective: Î¼âˆ’limit-fromğœ‡\mu-strong convexity of Fğ¹F and convexity and (Lw,Mâ€‹LÎ²)superscriptğ¿ğ‘¤ğ‘€superscriptğ¿ğ›½(L^{w},ML^{\beta})-smoothness of fmsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘šf_{m} for all mâˆˆ[M]ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘€m\in[M] (see AssumptionsÂ 1,Â 2). These assumptions are naturally satisfied for the vast majority of personalized FL objectives in the literature, with the exception of personalized FL approaches that are inherently nonconvex, such as MAMLÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017). Under these assumptions, we propose three algorithms for solving the general personalized FL objectiveÂ (1): i) Local Stochastic Gradient Descent for Personalized FL (LSGD-PFL), ii) Accelerated Block Coordinate Descent for Personalized FL (ACD-PFL), and iii) Accelerated Stochastic Variance Reduced Coordinate Descent for Personalized FL (ASVRCD-PFL). The convergence rates of these methods are summarized in TableÂ 1. We emphasize that these optimizers can be used to solve many (convex) personalized FL objectives from the literature by casting a given objective as a special case ofÂ (1), oftentimes matching or outperforming algorithms originally designed for the particular scenario.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4: The average wall-clock running time in seconds over 30 independent runs when solving the objectiveÂ (11). Each entry in the table reports the average time for 1,000 communication rounds. We ignore any additional communication costs that might occur in practice.

references: Results. The results are summarized in FigureÂ 1. We observe that our general-purpose optimizers are competitive with L2SGD+ and pFedMe. In particular, both ASVRCD-PFL and L2SGD+ consistently achieve the same training error as the other methods, which is well predicted by our theory. Although L2SGD+ is slightly faster in terms of convergence due to the specific parameter setting, it is not as general as the methods we propose. Furthermore, we note that the widely used LSGD-PFL suffers from data heterogeneity on different devices, whereas ASVRCD-PFL is not affected by this heterogeneity, as predicted by our theory. The average running time over 30 independent runs is reported in TableÂ 4.

S5.T5.caption: Table 5: The average wall-clock running time in seconds over 30 independent runs when solving the objectiveÂ (16) is presented. Each entry of the table reports the average time for 1,000 communication rounds. We ignore any additional communication costs that might occur in practice.
S5.T5.table:
5.0 10.0 15.0
LSGD 238.01 237.67 234.33
ASCD 17.00 16.55 16.46
ASVRCD 23.35 22.12 23.51
references: Results. The results are summarized in FigureÂ 2. When examining the training loss, we observe that ASCD-PFL drives the loss down quickly initially, while ASVRCD-PFL ultimately achieves a better optimum. This suggests that we can apply ASCD-PFL at the beginning of training and add control variates to reduce the variance at a later stage of training, thus combining the benefits of both algorithms. Both ASCD-PFL and ASVRCD-PFL perform much better than the widely used LSGD-PFL. When analyzing the estimation error, we observe that when the heterogeneity level is small, there is a tendency for overfitting, especially for ASCD-PFL; and when the heterogeneity level increases, there is less concern for overfitting. In general, however, ASCD-PFL and ASVRCD-PFL still achieve better estimation error than LSGD-PFL. The average running time over 30 independent runs is reported in TableÂ 5.
